Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Plasmonic Carbon dioxide to fuel photocatalysis by solar energy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is in the development of a transformative carbon dioxide sequestration technology that can convert carbon dioxide and water directly into gasoline fuels with unprecedented efficiency, with sunlight as the only energy input. The technology is based on earth abundant metals as photo-catalysts, is environment- friendly, and potentially can be used to mass-produce gasoline fuels at very low-cost. The ability to convert carbon dioxide into useful renewable energy source will not only decrease the carbon footprint but also transform the current energy infrastructure and reduce our country's energy dependence on fossil fuels.


This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is focused on developing a nano-enabled plasmonic photosynthesis technology for converting carbon dioxide into gasoline fuels in the presence of solar radiation. Preliminary laboratory scale experiments have demonstrated a solar-to-chemicals peak conversion efficiency of 8 to 10%. The proposal focuses on designing and building a bench-top semi-batch reactor to demonstrate the technical feasibility of the process and assess its technical and commercial potential for future scale up.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Phase I project, we have constructed and operated two kinds of scaled-up reactors: parallel-tubes & panel-shape; and built up an oil condensing system to collect and analyze the products.

A 10% of solar-to-chemical efficiency has been achieved for the plasmonic photocatalysis in the scaled-up parallel-tubes reaction system (200 cm2 reaction area, 100 times larger than the original reactor). We have identified the key parameters for the scaled-up photocatalysis testing as the shape and volume of the reactor, the temperature distribution and the reactant amounts in the reactor. The photocatalysis testing procedure has been improved to increase the reproducibility. A 99% reproducibility can be achieved in the scaled-up parallel-tubes reactor. The produced fuel can be used or sold as high quality gasoline with minimal preparation.

With this collecting system and parallel-tubes reactor, a layer of oil was collected, which can be used for visual demonstration. We believe that the plasmonic photocatalysis is both feasible in technological and market aspects. In the next step, a flow reactor at larger scale can be built to produce high purity hydrocarbons fuel at real-time. That prototype will show how this technology can be implemented in a large solar refinery that produces 7 million barrels of hydrocarbons fuel at $35/barrel per year.
